DarKnight, I agree with you. Unfortunately, parent crimes are the hardest to find out because the kid won't tell for two reasons:
 
 #1) If the kid is young enough, the parent can get the kid to believe that the abuse is normal. Thus, even if the kid is asked if he has been abused, the kid will respond with an honest no, because he actually does not think he has been.
 
 #2) The parent is probably the person who the child trusts the most. When he is abused, even if the kid knows it is wrong, the kid may lose that trust. When that trust is lost, there is no one who the child will feel like he can trust. Therefore, the child will choose not to tell anyone about it because there is no one who is "trustworthy enough" to know.
 
 
 I agree with Debate_Queen's sentence suggestions as minimum, and possibly more depending on the severity of the situation.
